chapters.title: Prologue
text: Aeroflot's flight Moscow - Los Angeles is one of the longest in the world and the longest among Russian airlines. And I hate long flights. Sleeping in a chair at ten thousand meters is not very good for me, so I try to kill the time with YouTube and music.

Finally the sunrise, and with it the last and most interesting part of the flight. The snowy fjords of Greenland show up in the window. Fuck, yeah! We are over the American continent and time is already starting to flow backwards!

You can also see something on the ground below. And if you hold your phone up to the window and use a map app (preferably offline ones like Maps.ME) to find your position, after about a minute you can see your current position and everything below you. Especially helpful when you want to know, for example, what is that huge lake on the border of the desert and mountains. It turned out to be Lake Tahoe.

Thanks to the screensaver on macOS, Yosemite is recognizable even from the air. Then all clouds disappear and we see the endless sun-drenched fields of central California below, here our plane hooks over a huge expanse of small houses pierced with long, curvy highways.

Please, fasten your seat belts. We have arrived in the City of Angels. It is the starting point of our road trip along the entire U.S. West Coast from south to north to Seattle and back. For several months me and my brother have thought out the idea and prepared the route, and now we are finally ready to go.

chapters.title: Los Angeles
text: When we arrived at check-in, a huge long line was waiting for us, wagging like a snake all over the huge hall, which seemed to have no limits. But in the end, after a single question about the purpose of our visit, the tired border guard stamped our passports and said, Welcome to the United States! Then we were looking for the right bus to the parking lot (LA airport is big and not very modern) and stood for 40 minutes in a traffic jam.

Car rental is done like this - you pay for the class of car and choose one from cars standing at the parking lot. Then you just get into the one you like and drive away. Our choice was the Chevrolet Equinox - a medium-sized crossover, almost nothing stands out, but it was the only car with Apple Car Play, and good navigation on the road is a must have.

From the airport we went to our hotel in the "city" of Torrance. The city is intentionally written in quotes, because it is literally just one of the districts of the Los Angeles metropolitan area. At least you can't see the border between the LA metropolitan area and the surrounding cities.

Hello jet-lag. After 24 hours without sleep you pass out almost immediately, but in the evening we decided to go out of the hotel to look at the ocean. All I remember is that it was warm, a beautiful sunset, neon signs, and the feeling that you were inside GTA 5.
We are only in LA for a day and a half. Nothing for such a huge city, but it's not the purpose of our trip either. Maybe next time.
Made it to the famous Santa Monica Beach with its freaks, bums, fishermen and surfers.
When you move around LA, you realize how huge it is in terms of distances. When you look at the map - it looks not far and you can even walk it, but it turns out to be 30-40 minutes by car.

In the evening we decided to climb the hills at the Griffith Observatory. It was such a mini trekking trip, there's a reason I brought my tracking shoes. The hills are not very steep, but they were perfect for hiking in the city, especially the views of downtown LA and the iconic letters HOLLYWOOD from the local trails. There were a few benches at the top of the hill and a few people who climbed up here, like us, to stare at the sunset.
Downtown Los Angeles fading into the haze, twilight, city noise in the distance, and occasional helicopters flying by.

We went down in the dark, lighting the trail with flashlights of iPhones, even wanted to take a shortcut, but when we reached the cliff (or maybe it just seemed so at night) we decided to return without any adventures. In the parking lot near the car we noticed a fuss - two dogs fighting, but as we got closer we realized it was two coyotes!
We decided to go back to Torrance via Downtown. But from the car window and at night we couldn't see much of anything.

It's time to say goodbye to the city of angels and hit the road, next time we will come back here only at the very end of the trip and only at the airport. But I would like to tell you about one more thing - the roads of Los Angeles. In fact, almost the entire city is an endless residential one-story blocks, stretching for tens of kilometers. And it would be quite impossible to move around it if there were not the freeways which pierce the city in all directions - Metropolitan Los Angeles Freeway System and which began to be built in the 1950s. The first time you are on the freeway it seems that everyone moves at a very high speed, and especially it is felt on a merging of two roads, because no one slows down, and it's not necessary - the freeways merge at a smooth angle and the limit on the "turn" is the same as on the straight section. But you get used to it very quickly and realize that the entire road system is very well thought out.

So the roads in the United States are great, especially their highway system. There are four main types of roads in the United States highway system. Each highway of any type has its own number and its own road sign with a unique design that makes it easy and quick to identify the road.

Interstates - the backbone of the U.S. highway network. The highways that carry millions of people across the country. Designed and built to specific standards for the most efficient and safe high-speed travel. Funded by the state, and maintained and repaired by the authorities of the state through which a section of road passes. They are globally numbered within the country, and on the road they are usually identified by a number on a blue and red shield.

U.S. highways - an older system of state highways, but since the advent of interstates, the role of this type of road has declined to medium-range travel, mostly within a single state. Can be built to high safety standards, or be a regular 2-lane road without a divider. Repair and maintenance of such roads is shared between state and local authorities. The numbering is similar to the interstate, and they are identified by a number on a white board.

State highways - as the name shows, roads within the same state. They are also built to different standards and their quality varies significantly. These roads are fully managed by the state authorities. They have their own intra-state numbering and the coolest badges (each state has its own design).

County highways - local roads in some states. They can be either major roads or unpaved roads leading to remote areas. The provision of such roads is entirely the responsibility of the local government. Signs, like the previous type of road, also have their own design and numbering.
In fact, there are other types of roads in some states, but not many and for the most part they are local roads. But we were waiting for a road number 1...
descr: Master plan of Metropolitan Los Angeles freeways, 1947

chapters.title: California 1
text: California State Route 1, SR1 or Pacific Coast Highway, is one of the most beautiful roads in the United States, running along most of the California coast, next to one of the most scenic coastlines in the world.

The road is 1,056 km long and begins near Dana Point (a small town southeast of LA). It is almost always along the coast, passing around numerous bays, going up into the mountains and back down to the water. It goes through two major metropolitan areas - Los Angeles and San Francisco, sometimes matching the 101 freeway on its way, and ending in the settlement of Leggett (where only 122 people live) in northern California. The road was not built all at once, but gradually in pieces since 1934 and was more of a collection of different roads until 1964, when it was given the number SR 1.

We decided not to do a detour to Dana Point, but just drove a couple of kilometers from the hotel to the ocean and took Highway 1 there. The next thing we had to do was to drive 1,000 kilometers on the one road.

We left Los Angeles early in the morning to avoid the traffic, but somehow we jammed anyway. The streets of the city, the suburbs, small satellite towns, and cottage communities-it would take more than a dozen miles to get out of civilization. But the cabins and parking lots became much rarer, and all that was left was the road, the sandy mountains on one side, the ocean on the other, and the occasional car with surfers along the curb. The atmosphere of a road trip was beginning to emerge.

Farther down the road from the coast, the road turns inland. There are hills and huge farm fields with Mexicans working in them. Occasionally, as we passed another farm, we got a strong smell of cannabis in the car. We never found out the exact cause, but since cannabis production and consumption is legal in California, it was probably "those" farms.

Some of the cities are very similar in style to Mexican or, well, Spanish cities. Not surprising, since California was not part of the United States until 1850, but was controlled by Mexico and Spain.
Making our first stop in the town of Morro Bay. We stop at Taco Bell and then to the ocean in the bay where the main local attraction, Morro Rock, is located.

Further on, the road passes through the famous Big Sur (not the operating system). Big Sur is an almost uninhabited wilderness area where the mountains abruptly drop off at the coast. It is very beautiful, there are almost no settlements and gas stations, and as a consequence, very expensive gasoline. Therefore, it is better to fill up in advance. The road here winds a lot, turning into a serpentine. There are special shoulders for slow cars - turnouts, where you can let the others go ahead.
We were unlucky with the weather and the whole coast was covered with thick fog, so we just had to believe that it was very beautiful here.

chapters.title: Monterey
text: When it started to get dark, we arrived in Monterey. I found out much later that there was a lot to see in the town. Then we just grabbed a six-pack of local IPA and headed out to celebrate the first day on the road.

chapters.title: Keep going
text: The motel in Monterey was a classic American movie motel, two floors and doors to the rooms right off the street. By the way, an interesting fact, many hotels (and this one was no exception) have a  Bible in every room. In God We Trust.
We leave the motel in the morning. Today we only have to drive 70 miles to San Jose. That's where our friend lives, who traded the cozy Moscow Khovrino for the eternal summer of California.
Driving along the coast, the scenery around the road would resemble a lifeless desert if there were not the huge number of farms with artificial irrigation.
The next town is Santa Cruz, known primarily for the manufacture of bicycles of the same name.
Here we pause our journey on Highway 1, and through the hills and serpentines we drive toward San Jose.

The picture outside the window changes dramatically. Instead of deserts and farms, there's a pine forest with huge trees along the sides of the road. The winding road climbs up, offering panoramic views of the surrounding countryside, and then down into the heart of the forest.

I will make a small digression. If you are planning a road trip in the USA, it is useful to know at least the basic differences between American and European traffic rules and the basic terms that you will encounter on the road. Below I've gathered some basic terms and concepts about U.S. roads.
Highway - in some contries this term is mistakenly used for an expressway or a freeway, but in fact the highway is just a road, any road even unpaved.
Divided / undivided highway - these terms refer to roads with or without a physical separator between oncoming traffic. There are even special signs for this.

Freeway - expressway. A highway built to special standards (for example, such highways do not intersect with other roads on the same level, and there are entrances and exits to such highways only in certain places) and designed for high-speed travel. All interstates in the United States are in this category.
Backroad - secondary road, for example, in the countryside.
Underpass - road passing under an overpass, bridge or other road.
No outlet - just like a dead end, but is not used for a single road, but for a network of roads from which there is only one entrance or exit.
Carpool lane - a special lane in which only cars with several people (at least 2, as a rule) or buses have the right to move.
Turnout - a special right-hand lane on narrow two-lane roads (usually in the mountains or hilly terrain) used by slow vehicles so that others can pass them.

Stop all-way - special intersections with Stop signs in all directions. Very common in California. When you approach such an intersection, you must stop and continue only if there is no interference. If you are approaching more than one car, the first car to pass will be the first one to pass.
Tailgating - not keeping the distance by the car moving behind, close to the car in front. It is considered a serious violation and you may be fined for it.

chapters.title: San Jose & San Francisco
text: From the hills we descend into one of the suburbs of San Jose. Although almost the whole city looks like a suburb - blocks of small one-story houses with small streets and a freeway a couple of kilometers away, cutting off all this quiet idyll from another one just like the previous one.

The contrast with other communities we've seen before is obvious. Here are some of the most expensive neighborhoods in the U.S., next door to Silicon Valley, the world center of IT technology. Perfect lawns, trees, roads, expensive cars and luxury homes.
Through the city's freeway system we reach our friend who lives in north San Jose. We spend the next few days here, making occasional trips into the neighborhood and into San Francisco.

Although San Francisco is close by (especially if you look at the map), it's at least an hour one-way. It could be more, depending on traffic. And in fact, it is San Francisco that is the only full-fledged city in the area, since downtown San Jose is really very small and compact.
The city itself is sometimes like New York, sometimes like Los Angeles. But even if it's smaller than those two cities, it definitely has a character of its own.

Much of the credit for this goes to the terrain. The city stands on many hills. That's why the streets here go down and up, looking from afar like completely steep walls, with houses somehow attached to them.
Downtown is pure New York City. Huge skyscrapers, people in suits and homeless with posters painted on cardboards.

And of course, the most important symbol of the city - the Golden Gate Bridge. A huge (2.7 km long) suspension bridge of red-brick color, in fact, the most famous bridge in the world. It was built in 1937 and linked two banks of the bay, almost 30 years remained the largest bridge in the world.

When we approached it, a very cold and strong wind was blowing from the ocean. And looking at the crowns of the trees bent toward the coast, it's a regular thing here. What's interesting is that literally a few kilometers inland and the climate changes, it becomes much warmer.

chapters.title: Further along the SR1
text: After a few days of rest, we hit the road again. And to save time, from San Jose to Santa Cruz we return on Highway 17.
The first highway again. The Pacific Ocean on the left, the hills on the right, and again we're heading north.
There are a lot of coves on the coast and again a lot of surfers.
The road winds along the shore going right on the edge of the ocean cliffs.
We enter San Francisco again. But this time we just drive through the city and across the Golden Gate Bridge to the other side of the bay.
Just over the bridge, we make a brief stop at the lookout to get one last look at the city, and then go on.
And then the real America begins. Simple, rural, made up of small towns and settlements. The road becomes narrower and the places wilder. The next big city is Portland, Oregon, after only 750 miles.
The coast here is higher and steeper. The road is serpentine and it's a bit tiring to drive along it, but at least the views are worth it.
We turn off the highway, into Point Reyes National Seashore, famous for its beautiful coastline.
There's also a tunnel of trees. A small driveway off the main road runs through rows of old cypress trees and ends in an old, abandoned marine radio station.
We don't reach the coast in the end, the road is bad, and the sun is already starting to set. We decide to return to civilization.
descr: Wreck of the ship Point Reyes

chapters.title: Santa Rosa
text: Surprisingly we find out that on Route 1, almost all hotel are booked. And the nearest available one is in the town of Santa Rosa.
So we turn inland and get there after dark.
Santa Rosa greets us with thick fog and Mexicans bustling in the hotel yard. What, however, only adds the vibe of a road movie.
Taking another 6-pack of California Hazy IPA. Another day on the road has come to its end.

chapters.title: California - Oregon
text: We leave the hotel early in the morning.
Yesterday's fog hasn't gone anywhere and everything is still shrouded in a thick haze.
Driving on country roads and everything around reminds me of the setting for Silent Hill.
We pass the small town of Sebastopol, the Russian River and some cafe with a Russian flag. Seems we just returned to our homeland harbor...
At the famous Fort Ross we arrive too early and it is still closed, we decide not to wait and drive on.
And again the road goes up on a hill, then down, almost to the water.
But then the road turns sharply inland and through a dense pine forest goes to the town (population just over 100 people) of Leggett.
This is where California State Route 1 ends, and as a reward for passing this way, you can of course drive through a huge sequoia tree and buy a magnet. Which we did (-$20).
From here on we continue our way on the 101 highway.
Clear weather alternates with foggy stretches and is starting to get dark soon.
Just after sunset, we come out of the woods onto a small coastal stretch.
We decide to make a quick stop here, enjoy the view and stretch out a little before the final throw to Oregon.
The road moves a bit away from the coast, from time to time showing the ocean. We drive through forests, hills, and small deserted towns.
Soon it gets completely dark and all you can see out the car window are just the glowing stripes of road lines and signs.
We drive another couple of hours in complete darkness and finally reach the hotel in Coos Bay, Oregon.

chapters.title: Oregon ü¶´
text: Welcome to the beaver state! As its official slogan says.
Breakfast with pancakes at a very authentic American diner and back on the road.
The weather in Oregon is much different than in California, variable cloudiness, occasional rain, and no sun (there will be almost none until we return to California on the way back).
Making a stop and climbing up to the old lighthouse on the coast, the Heceta Head Lighthouse. The lighthouse was built in 1892 and is still the most powerful on the entire Oregon coast.
But besides the lighthouse itself, the cape where it stands offers gorgeous views of the shoreline. The ocean was a bit stormy that day, so the scenery looked pretty rough.

A little farther along the coast are Thor's Well. These so-called salt water fountains are basically cracks in the coastal cliffs, filled with the force of the tide and periodically erupting ocean water.
The Oregon coast is actually incredibly gorgeous. And to really appreciate it, it would probably be better to choose some warmer time of year.
But there's also something about late fall with its endless rain. At least the absence of tourists and cars on the roads.
We reach the town of Newport with its huge Yaquina Bay Bridge, designed in Art Deco, Art Nouveau and Gothic architectural styles.
This is also where we turn off the 101 highway and off the coast toward the continent so we can make it to the hotel before the night.
descr: Views from the Heceta Head Lighthouse

chapters.title: Portland
text: Almost immediately after sunset we arrive in Portland, the largest city (but not the capital) of the state.
Two facts I knew about the city before that were that writer Chuck Palahniack lives here and that there are more breweries here than in any other city in the world.
On the way to the hotel, we stop at the observation point located on one of the city hills.
You can see the whole city center from here like on a palm of your hand. To bad the famous Mount Hood, which usually decorates the local skyline, can't be seen because of the cloud cover.
After the hotel, we go out for a little walk around Downtown.
There's almost nobody on the streets, I guess it's Fall and not the best weather.
The next morning we explore the city a little more around St. Johns Bridge.

Making a stop at the Portland Apple Store, there is no sales tax in Oregon and because of that here are the lowest prices for Apple devices, I take a new iPhone and will be shooting the trip with it quite often from now on.

chapters.title: Rainy Washington üå≤
text: We're leaving Portland and heading for the final destination of our journey, Seattle.
We decide to make a detour to the famous Multnomah Falls.
Over a bridge with the beautiful name Bridge of the Gods we cross the Columbia River and enter Washington State.
It's been raining all day and the further north you go, the harder it gets.
There's a significant increase in traffic on the approaches to Seattle, and traffic jams are starting to form.
It's finally getting dark, we're crawling slowly through the dense traffic.
A few hours with this pace and here comes the skyline of Downtown Seattle.
